Title: 2nd International Conference on Energy, Environment and Sustainable Development, EESD 2012
Abstract: The proceedings contain 375 papers. The special focus in this conference is on International Conference on Energy, Environment and Sustainable Development. The topics include: Investigation of lignite combustion characteristics with thermal analysis; pyrolysis characteristics of oil sands; study on factors influencing pulverized coal ignition time; the combustion analysis of coal under deflagration; thermal calculation on SAGD steam delivery system; flow and heat transfer in microchannels of the MTPV systems; numerical simulation of temperature field in the cyclone; piston secondary motion analysis considering head impact; abnormal heat by thermal changing in a D-Pd gas-loading system; orthogonal experimental research on sintering cooler transfer performance; development of micro rectangular channel gas cooler; research on engine-pump units adaptability in the plateau; bubble lift-off diameter prediction with new bubble growth model; research on signal simulator at crankshaft of motorcycle gasoline engine; resistance coefficient research of the train air supply orifice; analysis of drive performance of servo system for servo press; study of flow field and filtration efficiency in DPF; numerical simulation of temperature field in the cyclone; development of micro rectangular channel gas cooler; research on engine-pump units adaptability in the plateau; simulation of scavenging process in a two-stroke gasoline engine; resistance coefficient research of the train air supply orifice; analysis of drive performance of servo system for servo press; stress analysis of opening and offset nozzle on a cylinder; the mechanism of mangrove tree in wave energy propagation; analysis on load-undertaking of fan coil unit with fresh air system; numerical simulation on the characteristic of a solar chimney; design and study of resistance wave height meter; application of SVM-RBF to prediction of short-term load; a review on superconducting magnetic energy storage; study on protection for Islanded micro-grid; a negative sequence directional element for high-voltage line protections; power line measurement method based on vertical baseline stereo camera; survey of ambient excitation based power oscillation analysis methods; case study of voltage sag in customer substation; black-start subsystem partitioning based on nodes voltage; structural optimization of the GaAs-Based resonant tunneling diodes; piston stopping position detecting system of gasoline direction injection engine; multiple CMOS intersection measuring system modeling and analysis; a research and the application of a new graphite grousnding; reactive power optimization in distribution network with wind farm; experimental simulation on aerodynamic character of D-Shaped iced conductor; the SCR protection circuit evaluation in HV DEMOS devices; comparative analysis of the control rod drive system; based on ARM embedded remote data acquisition system; investigation of the soft-switched electron load; single defect in finite one dimensional photonic crystals; protection scheme for DC microgrid distribution system; overview on micro-grid technology; microgrid fault analysis based on multiple distributed generations; the economy and environmental benefit of the microgrid; study on key problems at power system black start; research on integrated management method for intelligent community.

Authors: West N., Ozoemena K.I., Ikpo C.O., Baker P.G.L., Iwuoha E.I.
Title: Transition metal alloy-modulated lithium manganese oxide nanosystem for energy storage in lithium-ion battery cathodes
Affiliations: Sensor Lab, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Cape, Bellville Cape Town, South Africa; Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, Pretoria, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: West, N., Sensor Lab, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Cape, Bellville Cape Town, South Africa; Ozoemena, K.I., Sensor Lab, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Cape, Bellville Cape Town, South Africa, Council for Scientific and Industrial Research, Pretoria, South Africa; Ikpo, C.O., Sensor Lab, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Cape, Bellville Cape Town, South Africa; Baker, P.G.L., Sensor Lab, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Cape, Bellville Cape Town, South Africa; Iwuoha, E.I., Sensor Lab, Department of Chemistry, University of Western Cape, Bellville Cape Town, South Africa
Abstract: This paper explores the synergistic and catalytic properties of a newly developed lithium ion battery (LIB) composite cathode of LiMn2O 4 modified with bimetallic (Au-Fe) nanoparticle. Spinel phase LiMn2O4 was doped with bimetallic nanoparticles, LiM xMn2-xO4 (M = FeAu), with concomitant oxidation of the Mn3+ ions (responsible for LIB capacity loss) to Mn 4+. This nano-composite architecture accommodates the structural transformation that occurs during Li+ ion charge and discharge. Ultra-low scan rate (0.01 mV s-1) cyclic voltammetry of the pure LiMn2O4 cathode material in 1 M LiPF6/ electrolyte solution, showed two sets of redox peaks with a third observed at lower potentials for LiMxMn2-xO4. The FeAu incorporation increased the reaction rate upon reduction of LiMn 2O4 as indicated by the enhanced reduction peak seen by cyclic voltammetry. Nyquist plots of the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) results showed LiFeAuxMn2-xO4 having increased conductivity with lower resistance of charge. X-ray diffraction studies showed the LiMxMn2-xO4 material retained well-developed octahedral structures bounded by (111) planes. The material crystallite size was ∼10 nm with clear lattice fringes having a separation value of 0.48 nm which concurrently improved the diffusion rate of Li+. Solid-state NMR results showed the progressive increase in average nominal manganese oxidation state from +3.5 to +4 resulted in an increase in the super-transferred hyperfine field at the 7Li nucleus of the FeAu doped cathode material. The LiFeAuxMn 2-xO4 material also showed improved cycleability, especially at high C rate. This improvement was due to the enhanced physical stability of LiMn2O4 and its improved electrical conductivity ascribed to the incorporated FeAu nanoparticles. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd.
Author Keywords: Cathode material; Charge transport; Doping; Lithium-ion battery; Nanomaterials
Index Keywords: Bimetallic nanoparticles; Cath-ode materials; Electrical conductivity; Lithium manganese oxide; Lithium-ion battery; Lithium-ion battery cathodes; Structural transformation; X-ray diffraction studies; Charge transfer; Cyclic voltammetry; Doping (additives); Electric conductivity; Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy; Gold; Lithium; Lithium alloys; Lithium batteries; Manganese; Nanoparticles; Nanostructured materials; Nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy; Transition metal alloys; X ray diffraction; Cathodes

Title: 2nd International Conference on Materials and Products Manufacturing Technology, ICMPMT 2012
Abstract: The proceedings contain 469 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Composites, Micro/Nano Materials and Technology, Steel, Iron and Technology, Ceramic, Metal Alloy Materials, Polymer Materials and Technology, Physics and Chemistry Materials and Technology, Building Materials, Energy Materials and Fuel Technology, Environmental Friendly Materials and Waste Recycling, Biomaterials, Chemical Materials and Processes, Thin Films, Earthquake Resistant Structures, Materials and Design, Surface Engineering/Coatings, Modeling, Analysis and Simulation, Materials Forming and Processes, Materials Machining, Welding and Joining, Mechanical Behavior and Fracture, Tooling Testing and Evaluation of Materials. The topics include: Fabrication and characterization of chromium-coated graphite fibers reinforced copper matrix composites; structure-property correlation of composites impregnated with aspartimide oligomer; study on the resin curing time and the mechanical properties of the composites; the slagging model research of refining-slag for high aluminum steel; evaluation of the direct tensile behavioral characteristics of uhpc using twisted steel fibers; stress characteristics analysis on a composite wind turbine blade; low grade of kyanite ore beneficiation experimental research in Xingtai; application of fiber reinforced composites for wushu equipment; Kyanite's status of beneficiation process and application; research on dual liquid bimetal composite casting lining board; synthesis and characterization of silver immobilized on glass fibers; infrared extinction properties of randomly oriented columnar nano-graphite particles; synthesis of silicon carbide nanoparticles from carbon nanotubes; silver nanoparticles with enhanced fluorescence effects on fluorescein derivative; applications of nanostructured materials as additives in space fluid lubricants; preparation of the silica micro-spheres by chemical precipitation process; application of nano-materials in sports engineering; effects of normalizing and tempering temperature on mechanical properties and microstructure of low alloy wear resistant steel casting; microstructure and mechanical properties of new type bainitic carburized steel for gear; effect of tempering temperature on microstructure and properties of cold deformed low carbon bainitic steel; influence of heat treatment on mechanical properties and microstructure of mining machinery steel plate containing molybdenum and niobium; study on sulfur control technology for non-oriented electrical steel; on the presence of eta carbide in the cryogenically treated high speed steel; analysis and practical application of extracting vanadium from hot metal in steel ladle; research on plastic inclusions control for steel cord; research on the effects of the refining treatment to the properties of dual-phase wear-resistant steel; effect of antimony on the structure, texture and magnetic properties of high efficiency non-oriented electrical steel; microstructure and properties of powder-forged steel; thermodynamic characterization in intercritical annealing process for dual-phases steels; laboratory research of the terpolymer fracturing fluid gelatinizer; using optical image real-time analysis software to characterize polymer processing; flocculation effects of hydrophobically modified polyacrylamides for tailing slurry; indomethacin molecular imprinted polymer preparation, characterization of application; study on properties of sulfonate hyperbranched polymer surfactant; the effect of thermal aging on properties of epoxy resin; elastomechanical study of magnetoeletric coupling in bilayer of lithium zinc ferrite and lead zirconate titanate; characteristics of photonic crystals on the total reflection tunneling with material absorption; research of fiber radar absorbing materials; fuzzy ball drilling fluids for CBM in the ordos basin of China; influence of pressure of electron gas on elastic property of metal; time-dependent density functional theory studies of plasmons in parallel double sodium atomic chains; photoinduced fluorescence switching of a new diarylethene and its application in optical recording storage; microwave-hydrothermal synthesis and characterization of graphene; study on the preparation of calcium sulfate whisker by hydrothermal method; numerical simulation of bionic wing for drag reduction; a production scheduling framework integrated with simulation module; numerical analysis on the butt-joint under izod impact test.

Title: Emerging Materials and Processes for Energy Conversion and Storage
Abstract: The proceedings contain 8 papers. The topics discussed include: copper coated LiCoO2 particles for water friendly electrodes in Li-ion batteries; effects of electrode modification on the air electrode for water electrolysis; effects of gas composition just before fuel pulses on power generation characteristics at different fuel supply frequency in pulse jet-rechargeable direct carbon fuel cells; improved effect of anode-additive PrBaInOx and Gd-doped BaCeO3 on the electrochemical performance of solid oxide fuel cells; electrochemical deposition of terbium from molten salts; photochemical route for the preparation of complex amorphous water oxidation catalyst; TiO2 as electron-extraction-layer in reverse type P3HT/ICBA organic solar cells; and continuous fabrication of SOFC assembly by ESD technique - dense thin film YSZ electrolyte.

Title: Kinder Morgan energy partners expands eagle ford shale footprint
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, LP (KMP) has entered into an agreement with a large Eagle Ford Shale producer to extend the Kinder Morgan Crude and Condensate (KMCC) pipeline farther into the Eagle Ford Shale in South Texas. In a $74 million investment, KMP will build an 18-mile, 24-inch lateral pipeline northwest from its DeWitt Station to a new facility in Gonzales County where 300,000 bbl of storage, a pipeline pump station and truck offloading facilities will be constructed. The 300,000-bpd lateral will enable KMP to batch Eagle Ford crude and condensate from the new Gonzales Station via KMCC to its delivery points on the Houston Ship Channel and/or the soon to be completed Sweeny Lateral pipeline serving the Phillips 66 Sweeny Refinery in Brazoria County.

Title: Romania, Hungary at loose ends for gas supply
Abstract: The termination of the Nabucco-West gas pipeline project leaves Romania and Hungary dependent on Russian gas imports. In countries without access to seaborne supplies of LNG, the post-Nabucco default options include building inter-connector pipelines with reverse-flow capability, adding gas storage capacities, and advancing energy market integration on a regional basis, within the EU's evolving energy market. The inter-connector pipeline Hungary-Croatia and the network inter-connection Hungary-Romania are already operational, with 6 and ≤ 5 billion cu m/yr capacities, respectively. The Slovakia-Hungary interconnector (with 5 billion cu m/yr capacity) is due for completion by 2015. However, the gas volumes actually available are nowhere near the capacities of those interconnectors. In Romania, the network interconnection with Hungary is not bi-directional. Romania seeks to prevent even a small-scale outflow of gas cheaply extracted in Romania toward higher-priced European markets.

Title: Meritage scoops up thunder creek gas services
Abstract: Meritage Midstream Services II LLC has acquired 100% ownership of Thunder Creek Gas Services LLC from Devon Energy Corp and PVR Partners LP. Meritage is also developing the Black Thunder Terminal, a joint venture with Arch Coal. Located in Campbell County, WY, at Arch Coal's Black Thunder mining complex, the terminal will provide storage, blending, and rail loading services for crude oil and condensate produced in the basin. Meritage plans to expand the Thunder Creek gathering system to provide pipeline service to the terminal.

Title: Crosstex energy completes phase II expansion at riverside
Abstract: The Crosstex Energy companies completed the Phase II expansion of its Riverside facility on the Mississippi River in southern Louisiana. The Riverside facility's capacity to transload crude oil from railcars to the partnership's barge facility has increased to 15,000 bpd. Phase II additions to the Riverside facility include a 100,000-bbl above-ground crude oil storage tank, a rail spur with a 26-spot crude railcar unloading rack, and a crude offloading facility with pumps, metering, and a truck unloading bay. As part of the Phase II expansion, Riverside was modified so sour crude can be unloaded in addition to sweet crude.

Title: TCE: United Kingdom: Welsh quarry battery will balance energy grid
Abstract: Gwynedd Council in North Wales, UK, has approved a planning permission to Quarry Battery Co (QBC) for a project to build a pumped energy storage system at a disused slate quarry site at Glyn Rhonwy. The 49.9 Mw hydroelectric scheme will provide ≤ 600 Mw-hr of back-up electricity to the grid at times of high demand. QBC's scheme is the most effective way of storing electricity and can replace some fossil fuel stations currently used at times of high demand. Construction will take ∼ 4 yr and use local materials.

Title: Sempra files permit to add facilities at Louisiana LNG terminal
Abstract: Sempra Energy filed a permit application with the FERC, requesting approval to begin construction of natural gas liquefaction and export facilities to its existing Cameron LNG terminal in Hackberry, LA. Construction will start in the fourth quarter of 2013. The liquefaction facility will utilize Cameron LNG's existing facilities, including two marine berths capable of accommodating Q-Flex-sized LNG ships, three LNG storage tanks of 480,000 cu m, and vaporization capability for regasification services of 1.5 bcf/day. The liquefaction facility will comprise three liquefaction trains with a total export capability of 12 million ton/yr of LNG. The facility is expected to begin delivering LNG in 2017.

Title: Lithuania LNG terminal plan delayed
Abstract: Lithuanian state-controlled energy terminal operator Klaipedos Nafta delayed approval of a contractor to build a link to connect its planned LNG terminal to the distribution grid pending a probe of the tender terms. This could hold back launch of the gas platform in late 2014. The disputed tender will build a 20-km pipeline linking the floating LNG terminal to Lithuania's gas distribution network by 10/1/2014. The 2 billion-3 billion cu m/yr regasification and storage facility is planned to go into operation by the end of 2014. The plan would end Lithuania's 100% reliance on imported Russian gas, hinges on unbundling national gas company Lietuvos dujos, which controls sales and the distribution network. The new Lithuanian government has exhibited a far less confrontational approach to Moscow, and plans to talk to Russia about the plan, although it maintains that it will carry it out.

Title: Kinder Morgan wraps up phase one at Bostco
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners (KMP) LP announced commercial operations are underway for phase one at the 185-acre Battleground Oil Specialty Terminal Co LLC (BOSTCO) project on the Houston Ship Channel. About 20 of the 51 storage tanks built during phase one were placed in service in October 2013 and the remaining tanks will come online in the next six months. The 7.1-MMbbl BOSTCO terminal is able to handle ultra-low sulfur diesel, residual fuels and other black oil terminal services. Phase two is underway and involves construction of six, 150,000-bbl, ultra-low sulfur diesel tanks, additional pipeline connectivity and high-speed loading at 25,000 bbl/hr. BOSTCO expects phase two to begin service in late 2014.

Title: Companies in the news: ABB has been chosen to supply process analyzers, system integration...
Abstract: ABB has been chosen to supply process analyzers, system integration, and related services for Cheniere Energy's Sabine Pass LNG export facility in Cameron Parish, LA. Located 4 mi from the Gulf Coast in southwestern Louisiana, the new export facility is being built by Bechtel as an expansion of Cheniere's existing Sabine Pass natural gas storage and import terminal. When completed, it will accommodate up to four LNG trains capable of processing ≈ 2 bcf/day of gas liquefaction for transport and potential export. The initial project under construction includes two trains with a liquefaction capacity of 1 bcf/day.

Title: ESI selected by OPA to implement synthesis
Abstract: Energy Solutions International (ESI) was selected by the UK's Oil and Pipelines Agency (OPA) and its operations and maintenance contractor to implement the Synthesis solution across the 1243-mi fuel pipeline and terminal network known as the Government Pipeline and Storage System (GPSS). The Synthesis platform will be implemented to meet the OPA's stock accounting requirements. The OPA is responsible for managing the GPSS for the UK Ministry of Defense.

Title: Western Europe NIBS: Spain: the government ordered a halt...
Abstract: The government ordered a halt to the injection of cushion-gas at the Castor gas storage facility, a depleted oilfield 22 km offshore from Valencia, Spain, after numerous small earthquakes along a stretch of the Mediterranean coast. Studies are being carried out, but Castor's owners (Spain's ACS and Canada's Dundee Energy) have said they will seek compensation if the facility is not allowed to start-up. Castor is designed to hold 1.3 billion cu m of gas.

Title: Lake Charles exports to build LNG liquefaction project
Abstract: The DOE provisionally approved Lake Charles LLC's application to export LNG to countries that do not have free trade agreements with the US. The project calls for the construction of three liquefaction trains with a total capacity of 15 ton/yr LNG, along with the use of existing LNG storage and marine berthing facilities. Pending final investment decisions from Energy Transfer and BG Group, Energy Transfer will complete financing for the potential project and begin construction in middle-2015, with projected in-service date in middle-2019.

Title: Crude oil/frac sand terminal planned in New Mexico
Abstract: Rangeland Energy expects to invest > $150 million in a terminal and supporting infrastructure in Loving, NM. The company has contracts to purchase 770 acres near Loving and plans to begin development of a terminal facility capable of handling crude oil, frac sand, pipe, and other products. A pipeline system is also planned in southern Eddy County, NM, to maximize terminal connectivity to existing and planned pipelines for both the receipt and delivery of crude oil. Rangeland will receive crude produced in southeast New Mexico and West Texas via inbound trucks and gathering pipelines. The terminal will provide crude oil storage and outbound access to existing and planned pipelines. Unit-train loading facilities will allow Rangeland's customers to deliver crude to markets across the country that are not accessible by pipeline.

Title: TCE: Africa: Africa's first underground gas storage planned for Nigeria
Abstract: UNIGAS, a gas transport company and Black Crystal Energy, a resource exploration and development company, are planning for a $2 billion underground gas storage facility in Nigeria - the first of its kind in Africa. The companies are seeking approval from Nigeria's Department of Petroleum Resources to use an abandoned or depleted oil or gas field for the project. The project will provide many benefits for Nigeria, by offering large-scale storage space for exports, improving efficiency in the domestic gas market, providing gas for national power stations, supporting heavy industries including cement, iron and steel, and petrochemicals, and overall, generate more revenue for the country from gas sales.

Title: Transportation: Quick takes: EPP to move diluent from Mont Belvieu to Chicago
Abstract: Enterprise Products Partners LP (EPP) will proceed with development of a project to transport diluent-quality natural gasoline from its Mont Belvieu, TX, liquids storage complex via its 20-in. OD TE Products Pipeline to several potential Chicago-area delivery points. The decision followed an open season during which EPP secured long-term commitments supporting plans to provide access to both Enbridge Inc's Southern Lights and Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP's Cochin pipelines. EPP expects connections to Southern Lights and Cochin to begin service during the fourth-quarter 2013 and second-quarter 2014, respectively.

Title: Kinder Morgan to expand Sweeny lateral pipeline
Abstract: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners entered into a long-term contract to support the expansion of its Sweeny lateral that it is building from the Kinder Morgan crude condensate pipeline to Phillip 66's refinery in Brazoria County, TX. The expansion will increase capacity on the 27-mi, 12-in. lateral from an initial 30,000 bpd to 100,000 bpd. Kinder Morgan will add new pumps and a 120,000-bbl storage tank at its Wharton pump station in Wharton County, TX, and increase the truck offload capabilities at its DeWitt station in DeWitt County, TX, to handle the higher capacity.

Title: CenterPoint, OGE, ArcLight capital form midstream MLP
Abstract: CenterPoint Energy Inc, OGE Energy Corp, and ArcLight Capital Partners LLC have entered into an agreement to form a master limited partnership that will include CenterPoint Energy's interstate pipelines and field services businesses and the midstream business of Enogex LLC, owned jointly by subsidiaries of OGE and Arclight. The partnership will be managed by a general partner whose governance will be shared by CenterPoint Energy and OGE on a 50:50 basis. The partnership will own and operate 8400 mi of interstate pipelines with ≈ 9 bcf of transport capacity and ≈ 2300 mi of intrastate pipelines. It will also have > 11,000 mi of gathering lines, which in 2012 moved ≈ 4 bcf/day of natural gas. It will also have > 90 bcf of natural gas storage capacity and 11 major processing plants with ≈ 2 bcf/day of inlet capacity.

Title: Double eagle pipeline system completed
Abstract: Double Eagle Pipeline LLC, a joint venture between Magellan Midstream Partners and Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP, has begun operation of the 85-mi western leg of its pipeline system moving condensate from Gardendale near Cotulla, TX, in LaSalle County to Three Rivers, TX. Operated by Kinder Morgan, the Double Eagle Pipeline includes 140 mi of new 12-in. pipeline connecting to a 50-mi, 14- and 16-in. pipeline segment extending from Three Rivers to Magellan's marine and storage terminal in Corpus Christi. The pipeline has initial capacity of 100,000 bpd but can be expanded to 150,000 bpd with additional pumps.

Title: Asia and Australasia: China: Shell is considering...
Abstract: Shell is considering building a LNG import terminal with Guanghui Energy in eastern China's Jiangsu province. Initially, Guanghui Energy plans to build LNG facilities in Qidong starting with a 600,000 ton/yr storage and transit plant. Under a second phase, the firm aims to build a 1.5 million ton/yr LNG import terminal and a 3.5 million ton/yr import plant in a third stage. All these investments are pending regulatory approvals. Shell would want to jointly invest and operate the facilities from the second phase, and the pair would explore the possibility of setting up a joint venture.

Title: Illinois drives natural gas infrastructure upgrades
Abstract: To leverage abundant natural gas supplies and low wholesale costs, Illinois employer and labor organizations and Ameren Illinois outlined a legislative proposal to accelerate the modernization of Illinois' aging natural gas delivery infrastructure while maintaining Illinois Commerce Commission regulatory oversight. Under the Natural Gas Modernization, Public Safety & Jobs Act, Ameren Illinois will invest $330 million and create 250 jobs to accelerate its ongoing work to strengthen and update its gas transmission, distribution and storage facilities in central and southern Illinois. The 10-yr blueprint will reduce non-hazardous leaks and trim maintenance costs while delivering long-term savings for customers. This is an opportunity for Illinois to develop an important long-term energy infrastructure strategy and plan that creates savings and benefits for our customers while helping grow the economy. The natural gas plan will help lay the foundation for economic development for years to come.

Title: Alliance to buy Kinder Morgan propane terminal
Abstract: Alliance Energy Services will acquire Kinder Morgan Energy Partners LP's (KMP) Benson, MN, propane terminal for $5 million. The terminal supplies > 75 million gal/yr from the Cochin Pipeline System and has a storage capacity of ∼ 1.4 million gal. KMP will quit receiving propane into Cochin next spring prior to the company's Cochin Reversal Project, which involves the modification of the western leg of its pipeline. The move will allow light condensate to move northwest from Kankakee County, IL, to terminal facilities near Fort Saskatchewan, Alberta. Propane deliveries to the terminal are expected to continue until May 2014.

Title: Transportation: Quick takes: Double Eagle pipeline begins condensate shipments
Abstract: Double Eagle Pipeline LLC, a 50:50 joint venture of Magellan Midstream Partners and Kinder Morgan Energy Partners, has started shipping condensate for Eagle Ford shale producers in Karnes and Live Oak counties, TX. Double Eagle line-fill ended, with the system now transporting condensate via KMEP's existing 50-mi, 14-in. and 16-in. OD pipeline from Three Rivers, TX, to Magellan's Corpus Christi, TX, terminal. Double Eagle's new truck unloading and storage facility near Three Rivers also entered service. The joint venture expects to complete construction of Double Eagle's 140-mi, 12-in. OD western leg from Gardendale near Cotulla, TX, in LaSalle County to Three Rivers in the third quarter of 2013. Initial capacity of the pipeline is 100,000 bpd, expandable to 150,000 bpd with additional pumps. Double Eagle was initially proposed by a joint venture consisting of Copano Energy LLC and Magellan. KMEP purchased Copano in early 2013.

Title: Holly energy's crude system expansion in new Mexico
Abstract: Holly Energy Partners (HEP) is proceeding with expansion of its crude oil transportation system in southeastern New Mexico in response to increased crude oil production. The expansion will provide additional pipeline takeaway capacity to either common-carrier pipeline stations for transportation to major crude oil markets or to Holly Frontier's New Mexico refining facilities. HEP will convert an existing refined products pipeline to crude oil service, construct several pipeline segments, expand an existing pipeline, and build truck unloading stations and crude storage capacity. Excluding the value of the existing pipeline to be converted, total expenditures are expected to be $35-$40 million. HEP estimates the project will provide increased capacity of ≤ 100,000 bpd across its system and anticipates it will be in service no later than early 2014.

Title: West Texas gateway and justice NGL pipelines begin service
Abstract: The 570-mi, 16-in. West Texas Gateway NGL Pipeline, which extends from Winkler County in West Texas to ETP's Jackson County processing plant in Jackson County, has been placed in service. Owned by Lone Star NGL LLC, the pipeline transports NGL produced in the Permian and Delaware basins in West Texas to Mont Belvieu, TX, and has an initial capacity of 209,000 bpd with the potential to increase capacity. Energy Transfer Partners LP also placed its 130-mi Justice NGL Pipeline, extending from the Jackson County processing facility to Mont Belvieu, in service. Lone Star has secured capacity on ETP's Justice NGL pipeline for ultimate delivery of NGL to Lone Star's storage and fractionation facilities at Mont Belvieu.

Title: ECS Electrochemical Energy Summit - 222nd ECS Meeting/PRiME 2012: Grand Challenges for Energy Conversion and Large Scale Energy Storage
Abstract: The proceedings contain 1 paper. The topics discussed include: issues and challenges for implementation of large-scale energy storage in Australia.

Title: Intercalation Compounds for Rechargeable Batteries
Abstract: The proceedings contain 20 papers. The topics discussed include: surface control and multi-composite cathodes; bimetallic sulfates A2M(SO 4)2.nH2O (A = Li, Na and M = transition metal): as new attractive electrode materials for Li- and Na-ion batteries; revisiting the lithium iron borate (LiFeBO3) cathode system: synthetic and electrochemical findings; rechargeable batteries: from hybrid materials to devices; novel mesoporous nanotitania/carbon composite electrodes for electrochemical energy storage; improvement of cycle performance of lithium-ion batteries at elevated temperature of 60°C using graphite coated with metal oxide; electrochemical intercalation of bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl) imide anion into various graphites for dual-ion cells; olivine materials for positive electrodes in Li-ion batteries: electronic properties; and MnO2 nano-rods prepared by redox reaction as cathodes in lithium batteries.

Title: Batteries and Energy Technology (General Session) - 222nd ECS Meeting/PRiME 2012: In Honor of James McBreen
Abstract: The proceedings contain 14 papers. The topics discussed include: an empiric approach to state of charge assessment and range estimation of an electric vehicle; a conjugated sulfide-polymer battery with variable capacitance controlled by redox reaction; comparison of pocket plate and sintered plate Ni electrodes used in energy storage technologies for PV back up applications; graphene as a conductive additive to improve the performance of layered LiNi0.66Co0.17Mn0.17O2 for lithium-ion batteries; polymorphic behavior and morphology of electrospun poly(vinylidene fluoride) separator materials for non-aqueous electrolyte based electric double layer capacitors; direct measurement of vanadium crossover in an operating vanadium redox flow battery; the hydrogen fuel cell vehicles powertrain possible roles in the Kyoto protocol second commitment period perspective in the Pacific rim area; and study of the kinetics of vanadium (II)/(III) redox reaction.

Title: Emerging Materials and Processes for Energy Conversion and Storage
Abstract: The proceedings contain 7 papers. The topics discussed include: synthesis and electrochemical properties of Ni doped spinel LiNixMn2-xO4 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.5) cathode materials for Li-ion battery; new paradigms for cost-effective III-V photovoltaic technology; electrodeposited CIS and CIGS-based solar cells; one-step electrochemical deposition of Cu-In-Ga mixed oxide thin films for low-cost CIGS solar cells; graphene-quantum dots composite for photovoltaic devices; XRD and Raman spectroscopy study of Fe solubility in cerium oxide; and development of electrically controlled energetic materials (ECEM).

Title: 21st International Materials Research Congress, IMRC 2012
Abstract: The proceedings contain 24 papers. The special focus in this conference is on Composites, Coatings, Electron Microscopy and X-Ray Diffraction. The topics include: Characterization of the thermoelectric behavior of plastically deformed steels by means of relative seebeck coefficient; elimination of Al4C3 phase in Al/SiCP composites by HYSYCVD; spectroscopy study of silver nanoparticles produced by chemical reduction; effects of welding conditions by TIG and post weld heat treatment in ductile cast iron on the corrosion resistance; characterization of the microstructural degradation of platinum modified aluminide coating; analysis of weld bead parameters of overlay deposited on D2 steel components by plasma transferred Arc (PTA) process; high-energy ball-milling of FeAl2 and Fe2Al5 intermetallic systems; structural, textural and thermal characterization of Nano-Mg/Al Hydrotalcite before and after Cr (VI) removal; characterization of Pt-Pd bimetallic nanoparticles by Cs-Corrected STEM; fabrication and characterization of highly ordered porous alumina templates by a two-step anodization process; Ag nanoparticles adsorption on diatom-montmorillonite clays; electrochemical characterization of the structural metals immersed in natural seawater: in situ measures; crystallization and properties of glass-ceramics of the K2O-BaO-B2O3-Al2O3-TiO2 system; structural evolution of FeAl3 intermetallic during high-energy ball-milling; chemical characterization of yellow and orange pollen (helianthus annuus) and its effect in the growth of hydroxyapatite and microstructural behavior during bonding of alumina to niobium by liquid state diffusion.

Authors: Elitzur S., Rosenband V., Gany A.
Title: High energy density storage using in-situ hydrogen production
Affiliations: Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa 32000, Israel; Sylvia and David IA Fine Rocket Propulsion Center and the Aerothermodynamics Lab, Israel
Authors with affiliations: Elitzur, S., Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa 32000, Israel; Rosenband, V., Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa 32000, Israel; Gany, A., Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa 32000, Israel, Sylvia and David IA Fine Rocket Propulsion Center and the Aerothermodynamics Lab, Israel
Abstract: This paper presents a novel method for high energy density storage using in-situ hydrogen production from the chemical reaction between aluminum and water at room temperature. It further demonstrates the application in PEM fuel cells. The reaction between aluminum and water is possible due to a special thermo-chemical activation process developed at the Technion. Only a small fraction of activator is used (typically 2.5%) demonstrating high reaction rates. The aluminum and water reaction yields about 11% hydrogen based on the aluminum mass. When applied in PEM fuel cells it is equivalent to electric energy storage of about 2.2 kWh per kg aluminum.
Index Keywords: Aluminum; Chemical activation; Energy conversion; Hydrogen storage; Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC); Reaction rates; High energy densities; PEM fuel cell; Technion; Water reaction; Hydrogen production

Title: Design of a piano-keyweir for giritale dam spillway in sri lanka
Source title: Labyrinth and Piano Key Weirs II
Affiliations: Ministry of Irrigation and Water Resources, Colombo, Sri Lanka; Irrigation Department, Colombo, Sri Lanka
Authors with affiliations: Jayatillake, H.M., Ministry of Irrigation and Water Resources, Colombo, Sri Lanka; Perera, K.T.N., Irrigation Department, Colombo, Sri Lanka
Abstract: Giritale Reservoir in Sri Lanka (2 300 hm3), irrigates 3 077 ha in two seasons of the year and its capacity is about 1/2 the seasonal irrigation demand. Working as an on-line reservoir, it is mainly fed by diversions from Mahaweli River System. Since recent, water shortages have been experienced towards end of cropping seasons severely affecting the livelihoods of people settled in the scheme. If the reservoir capacity can be increased, additional diversions from Mahaweli are possible to mitigate the problem. Reservoir is located in a developed area and inundation is a serious limitation when increasing the capacity. With the adoption of PKW, capacity could be increased by 15% without increasing dam height and with minimum inundation. An optimized stepped slope configuration for energy dissipation was incorporated in downstream to minimize tail works. Economy of increasing storage using PKWs against construction of new reservoirs is also presented. © 2014 by Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Thermal analysis and design of passive solar buildings
Source title: Thermal Analysis and Design of Passive Solar Buildings
Authors with affiliations: Athieniti, A.K.; Santamouris, M.
Abstract: Passive solar design techniques are becoming increasingly important in building design. This design reference book takes the building engineer or physicist step-by-step through the thermal analysis and design of passive solar buildings. In particular it emphasises two important topics: the maximum utilization of available solar energy and thermal storage, and the sizing of an appropriate auxiliary heating/cooling system in conjunction with good thermal control. Thermal Analysis and Design of Passive Solar Buildings is an important contribution towards the optimization of buildings as systems that act as natural filters between the indoor and outdoor environments, while maximizing the utilization of solar energy. As such it will be an essential source of information to engineers, architects, HVAC engineers and building physicists. © 2002 A K Athienitis and M Santamouris.
Index Keywords: Engineers; Heat storage; Passive solar buildings; Solar energy; Thermoanalysis; Auxiliary heating; Building engineers; Buildings as systems; In-buildings; Outdoor environment; Passive solar design; Thermal control; Thermal storage; Architectural design

Title: Roof cooling techniques: A design handbook
Source title: Roof Cooling Techniques: A Design Handbook
Authors with affiliations: Yannas, S.; Molina, J.L.
Abstract: Natural heating and cooling of buildings helps to improve energy efficiency in the built environment. This book considers the principles of roof design and specific systems and cooling techniques. The authors explain the fundamental principles of roof cooling and describe in detail the relevant components, applications, built precedents, recent experimental work and key design considerations. Specific systems and techniques are examined, including the main advantages and disadvantages of each strategy. Environmental functions are considered in terms of protective strategies and selective strategies. Protective strategies include solar control, thermal insulation, heat storage and thermal inertia. Selective strategies include radiative, evaporative and convective cooling and planting of roofs. Traditional and current roof construction practices are described, exemplified by case studies from across Europe. Including a free CD-ROM with software that enables readers to evaluate their own designs, this book will be invaluable for architects and engineers who wish to create buildings that are more energy-efficient. © Simos Yannas, Evyatar Erell and Jose Luis Molina, 2006. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Cooling systems; Energy efficiency; Heat storage; Thermal insulation; Convective cooling; Design considerations; Environmental functions; Fundamental principles; Heating and cooling of buildings; Relevant components; Roof constructions; Selective strategies; Roofs

Title: The role of the network planning process in upgrading network functionality to meet the requirements of independent power producers
Affiliations: AECOM, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Horvath, G.C., AECOM, New Zealand
Abstract: The relevance and the implications of Distributed Resources (DR) to the Network Services provided by network services providers is trying to undergo a revolution, which reflects the strong emphasis being placed on the uptake of DR within the energy policies of many countries. However, a bottleneck has formed through the inability of the energy networks to respond to the needs of DR at the volumes which would reflect the aspirations of the policy makers. This paper explores the idea that if the connection requirements of DR were integrated into the NSPs' planning processes then, more convenience and assurance could be achieved for DR proponents, thereby reducing the well-known non-price barriers to DR connection that has been a back-wind in realising the energy policies of many jurisdictions. The approach suggested in the paper, is to consider the accommodation by NSPs of the needs of DR, (whether it be wind resource, or PV, or a range of other resources such as intermittent storage), as a range of new Network Services that an NSP needs to provide at its points of interconnection with the grid. Then, through the normal Planning Process, and through the governance provided by the regulator, an NSP can work systematically, a) to define the levels of the new Network Services that it is able to provide at each POI; and b) to match the network capability to the expected demands for these Services that will manifest over the current planning cycle. Any shortfall can then be made good through the normal regulatory approval of CAPEX. Certainty is provided to prospective DR connectors through framing the new Network Services so as to be supportive and complying with their needs. However the expected impacts on the network of the forecast demand for DR connections, and therefore the new network services, are determined by the normal techniques of simulation utilised in a standard planning processes. © 2018 Israel Annual Conference on Aerospace Sciences. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Distributed generation; Distributed resources; Network planning; Regulation of networks
Index Keywords: Distributed power generation; Energy policy; Wind power; Connection requirements; Distributed resources; Independent power producers; Network functionality; Network planning; Network planning process; Network services providers; Regulatory approvals; Electric utilities

Source title: 2013 Sustainable Internet and ICT for Sustainability, SustainIT 2013

Title: H2TRUST for hydrogen sustainability and safety
Abstract: Nine European partners, including associations, major companies, universities, technology and research centers from seven countries, have launched the H2TRUST consortium. The objective of the project is to foster a smooth and well managed transition to full-scale commercialization of fuel cell and hydrogen applications in Europe, and emphasize the importance of hydrogen safety among all stakeholders. Co-funded by the European Commission-supported Fuel Cells and Hydrogen Joint Undertaking, the H2TRUST consortium will run until November 2014. The project is led by Barcelona-based MATGAS, a joint venture between Air Products, the National Research Council of Spain, and the Autonomous University of Barcelona. The consortium members include Air Products, European Hydrogen Association, Solvay Speciality Polymers Italy, Politecnico di Milano, McPhy Energy in France, SOL SpA and CiaoTech (PNO Group) in Italy, and Eindhoven University of Technology in the Netherlands. One of the consortium's main goals is to evaluate industry efforts to ensure fuel cell and hydrogen technology remains safe, and that there is adequate regulation, hazard awareness, incident readiness, and ability to respond to any public concerns. Risk assessments will focus on each of the main application areas: hydrogen production, storage and distribution, mobility and vehicles, non-vehicles, and residential power generation.

Title: Exohedral metallofullerenes
Affiliations: Institute of Colloid and Water Chemistry, Varnadsky blvd 42, Kiev, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Loboda, O., Institute of Colloid and Water Chemistry, Varnadsky blvd 42, Kiev, Ukraine
Abstract: Fullerene-based materials have attracted considerable interest since the discovery of C60. A promising area of research concerns metal–fullerene interactions and their application to advanced nano materials, with potential use in optical and switching devices, as photoconductors, and for hydrogen storage. Moreover, transition metal complexes of fullerenes show catalytic activity in homogeneous hydrogenation of acetylenic alcohols [1] and hydroformylation of alkenes [2]. In heterogeneous catalysis, exohedral metallofullerenes are found to promote hydrogenation of olefins and acetylenes [3, 4] as well as reduction of carbon monoxide to methane [5, 6]. © 2012, Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.
Author Keywords: Bond dissociation energy; Bond dissociation energy; Fullerene molecule; Metal atom; Transition metal atom
Index Keywords: Bond strength (chemical); Carbon monoxide; Catalysis; Catalyst activity; Dissociation; Hydrogen storage; Hydrogenation; Metal complexes; Olefins; Transition metal compounds; Transition metals; Acetylenic alcohols; Bond dissociation energies; Fullerene molecules; Hydrogenation of olefins; Metal atoms; Metallofullerenes; Switching devices; Transition metal atoms; Fullerenes

Title: Modelling embedded technologies in energy service networks
Source title: Modelling Distributed Energy Resources in Energy Service Networks
Abstract: The chapter begins by explaining how to model a complex OLTC in electrical systems and then is followed by compressor unit modelling in gas systems. Subsequently, CHP and PHEV devices are portrayed, giving especial emphasis to the storage features they bring along to the integrated load flow problem. Laying a consistent framework for the representation of control mechanisms and distributed resources creates the opportunity to explore the operating trade-offs and interdependency relationships new technologies can have on energy service networks. © The Institution of Engineering and Technology 2013.

Authors: Kurnitski J., Achermann M., Gräslund J., Hernandez O., Zeiler W.
Title: nZEB case studies
Affiliations: Tallinn University of Technology, Ehitajate tee 5, Tallinn, 19086, Estonia
Authors with affiliations: Kurnitski, J., Tallinn University of Technology, Ehitajate tee 5, Tallinn, 19086, Estonia; Achermann, M., Tallinn University of Technology, Ehitajate tee 5, Tallinn, 19086, Estonia; Gräslund, J., Tallinn University of Technology, Ehitajate tee 5, Tallinn, 19086, Estonia; Hernandez, O., Tallinn University of Technology, Ehitajate tee 5, Tallinn, 19086, Estonia; Zeiler, W., Tallinn University of Technology, Ehitajate tee 5, Tallinn, 19086, Estonia
Abstract: There already exist pilot projects across Europe, which may be called nZEB buildings. They are not easy to compare because of variation in the definitions and performance levels—nZEB definitions have not yet been available when these buildings have been designed. It is important to check which energy uses are included in the calculated and measured energy performance and are the results reported as delivered or primary energy. Tenant’s electricity (appliances, lighting) is often not included. Simulated primary energy is typically between 50 and 100 kWh/(m2 a) for high-performance nZEB buildings with on-site renewable energy production if all energy uses are included. Such buildings may be extremely complicated, e.g. control of mixed mode ventilation or integrated energy supply solutions with storage and many operation modes. “Overkill” complexity may have implications on operation and maintenance as nobody cannot manage systems, which are not easy to control and operate. Another trend that can be seen is simple and reliable solutions based on high-performance components and careful system design and fitting with building properties. In the following, five nZEB buildings across the Europe are reported. Three of them are with measured energy data, indicating that strict targets are not always easy to achieve; however, some deviations have been caused also by unrealistic energy calculation input data. Technical solutions used show that there are many alternative ways to achieve high performance; however, strong differences in design bases and basic solutions in similar climate may also show that optimal solutions are always not known or found. Four first case studies are mostly focused on description of technical solutions, but the last one also describes the tuning of systems needed in the first year of operation to achieve the targets. © 2013, Springer-Verlag London.

Title: Hybrid metal nanoparticle-semiconductor nanowire assemblies: Synthesis, properties and applications
Source title: Handbook of Functional Nanomaterials: Synthesis and Modification
Affiliations: Nanotechnology Research Center (NRC), Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, University of Cyprus, Nicosia, Cyprus
Authors with affiliations: Krasia-Christoforou, T., Nanotechnology Research Center (NRC), Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, University of Cyprus, Nicosia, Cyprus; Zervos, M., Nanotechnology Research Center (NRC), Department of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, University of Cyprus, Nicosia, Cyprus
Abstract: Hybrid, semiconductor nanowire - metal nanoparticle assemblies have been investigated extensively in the context of nanotechnology for the development of novel sensors, solar cells, memory, energy storage and catalysis applications. In most cases silicon and metal - oxide semiconductor nanowires have been functionalized with noble metal nanoparticles. The large surface to volume ratio and high aspect ratio of semiconductor nanowires combined with the size dependent physical and chemical properties of noble metal nanoparticles make semiconductor nanowire - metal nanoparticle assemblies very attractive since one may achieve high device performances. Critical issues include control and modification of the surface properties of semiconductor nanowires for anchoring of noble metal nanoparticles but also the realization of ordered assemblies rather than random aggregates. Here we review the state of the art on the synthesis but also on the physical and chemical properties of semiconductor nanowires functionalized with noble metal nanoparticles such as Ag, Au, Pt and Pd with particular emphasis on their application for gas sensors, surface enhanced raman scaterring sensors, resistance switching memories, supercapacitors and batteries but also for their application in photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. © 2014 Nova Science Publishers, Inc.

Title: Nuclear energy: Overview of congressional issues
Source title: The Transformation of Electrical Power: Key Issues
Authors with affiliations: Holt, M.
Abstract: The policy debate over the role of nuclear power in the nation's energy mix is rooted in the technology's fundamental characteristics. Nuclear reactors can produce potentially vast amounts of energy with relatively low consumption of natural resources and emissions of greenhouse gases and other pollutants. However, facilities that produce nuclear fuel for civilian power reactors can also produce materials for nuclear weapons. The process of nuclear fission (splitting of atomic nuclei) to generate power also results in the production of radioactive material that must be contained in the reactor and can remain hazardous for thousands of years. How to manage the weapons proliferation and safety risks of nuclear power, or whether nuclear power is worth those risks, are issues that have long been debated in Congress. The 104 licensed nuclear power reactors at 65 sites in the United States generate about 20% of the nation's electricity. Five new reactors are currently licensed for construction. About a dozen more are planned, but whether they move forward will depend largely on their economic competitiveness with natural gas and coal plants. Throughout the world, 436 reactors are currently in service, and 62 more are under construction. The March 2011 disaster at the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power plant in Japan increased attention to nuclear safety throughout the world. The U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC), which issues and enforces nuclear safety requirements, established a task force to identify lessons from Fukushima applicable to U.S. reactors. The task force's report led to NRC's first Fukushima-related regulatory requirements on March 12, 2012. Several other countries, such as Germany and Japan, eliminated or reduced their planned future reliance on nuclear power after the accident. Highly radioactive spent nuclear fuel that is regularly removed from nuclear power plants is currently stored at plant sites in the United States. Plans for a permanent underground repository at Yucca Mountain, NV, were abandoned by the Obama Administration, although that decision is being challenged in court. The Obama Administration appointed the Blue Ribbon Commission on America's Nuclear Future to recommend an alternative nuclear waste policy. The Commission recommended in January 2012 that new candidate sites for nuclear waste storage and disposal facilities be selected through a "consent based" process. The level of security that must be provided at nuclear power plants has been a highprofile issue since the 9/11 terrorist attacks on the United States in 2001. Since those attacks, NRC issued a series of orders and regulations that substantially increased nuclear plant security requirements, although industry critics contend that those measures are still insufficient. Encouraging exports of U.S. civilian nuclear products, services, and technology while making sure they are not used for foreign nuclear weapons programs has long been a fundamental goal of U.S. nuclear energy policy. Recent proposals to build nuclear power plants in several countries in the less developed world, including the Middle East, have prompted concerns that international controls may prove inadequate. © 2013 Nova Science Publishers, Inc.

Title: U.S. spent nuclear fuel storage
Source title: Spent Nuclear Fuel: Storage Options and Efforts
Authors with affiliations: Werner, J.D.
Abstract: Regardless of the outcome of the ongoing debate about the proposed Yucca Mountain geologic waste repository in Nevada, the storage of spent nuclear fuel (SNF)-also referred to as "high-level nuclear waste"-will continue to be needed and the issue will continue to be debated. The need for SNF storage, even after the first repository is opened, will continue for a few reasons. First, the Obama Administration terminated work on the only planned permanent geologic repository at Yucca Mountain, which was intended to provide a destination for most of the stored SNF. Also, the Yucca Mountain project was not funded by Congress in FY2011 and FY2012, and not included in the Administration's budget request for FY2013. Second, even if the planned repository had been completed, the quantity of SNF and other high-level waste in storage awaiting final disposal now exceeds the legal limit for the first repository under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act (NWPA). Third, the expected rate of shipment of SNF to the repository would require decades to remove existing SNF from interim storage. Accordingly, the U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) and reactor operators are considering extended SNF storage lasting for more than 100 years. The debate about SNF typically involves where and how it is stored, as well as what strategies and institutions should govern SNF storage. The earthquake and tsunami in Japan, and resulting damage to the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power plant, caused some in Congress and NRC to consider the adequacy of protective measures at U.S. reactors. The NRC Near-Term Task Force on the disaster concluded it has "not identified any issues that undermine our confidence in the continued safety and emergency planning of U.S. plants." Nonetheless, NRC has accepted a number of staff recommendations on near-term safety enhancement, including requirements affecting spent fuel storage and prevention and coping with station blackout. NRC is not requiring accelerated transfer of SNF from wet pools to dry casks, but the SNF storage data from the last several years indicate that accelerated transfer has already been occurring. As of December 2011, more than 67,000 metric tons of SNF, in more than 174,000 assemblies, is stored at 77 sites (including 4 Department of Energy (DOE) facilities) in the United States located in 35 states (see Table 1 and Figure 5), and increases at a rate of roughly 2,000 metric tons per year. Approximately 80% of commercial SNF is stored east of the Mississippi River. At 9 commercial SNF storage sites there are no operating nuclear reactors (so-called "stranded" SNF), and at the 4 DOE sites reactor operations largely ceased in the 1980s, but DOE-owned and some commercial SNF continues to be stored at DOE facilities. In the United States, SNF is stored largely at nuclear reactor sites where it was generated. Of the 104 operating nuclear reactors in the United States, all necessarily have wet storage pools for storing SNF (wet pools are required to allow for a safe "cooling off" period of 1 to 5 years after discharge of SNF from a reactor). Wet storage pools are used for storage of approximately 73% (49,338 out of 67,450 metric tons of uranium, or MTU) of the current commercial SNF inventory, whereas the remaining 27% (18,112 MTU) of commercial SNF is stored in dry casks on concrete pads or in vaults. As wet storage pools become filled to capacity using "dense packing" storage methods, dry storage is increasingly being used, although there are 27 sites with 36 wet storage pools with no dry cask storage capabilities. This chapter focuses on the current situation with spent nuclear fuel storage in the United States. It does not address all of the issues associated with permanent disposal of SNF, but rather focuses on the SNF storage situation, primarily at current and former reactor facilities for the potentially foreseeable future. © 2012 Nova Science Publishers, Inc.

Title: Marcellus shale and shale gas: Facts and considerations
Source title: Marcellus Shale and Shale Gas: Facts and Considerations
Authors with affiliations: Navarro, G.L.
Abstract: The Marcellus Shale is a sedimentary rock formation deposited over 350 million years ago in a shallow inland sea located in the eastern United States where the present-day Appalachian Mountains now stand. This shale contains significant quantities of natural gas. New developments in drilling technology, along with higher wellhead prices, have made the Marcellus Shale an important natural gas resource. This book explores water resources and natural gas production from the Marcellus Shale; the impact of Marcellus Shale gas play on current and future Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS) activities and applying this technology to solve America's energy challenges. © 2011 by Nova Science Publishers, Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Pyatnichko O., Zhuk H., Bannov V., Kubenko S.
Title: System of landfill gas collection and utilization
Source title: International Journal of Energy for a Clean Environment
Affiliations: Gas Institute, National Academy of Sciences, 39 Degtyarivska St., Kiev, 03113, Ukraine
Authors with affiliations: Pyatnichko, O., Gas Institute, National Academy of Sciences, 39 Degtyarivska St., Kiev, 03113, Ukraine; Zhuk, H., Gas Institute, National Academy of Sciences, 39 Degtyarivska St., Kiev, 03113, Ukraine; Bannov, V., Gas Institute, National Academy of Sciences, 39 Degtyarivska St., Kiev, 03113, Ukraine; Kubenko, S., Gas Institute, National Academy of Sciences, 39 Degtyarivska St., Kiev, 03113, Ukraine
Abstract: The system for collection and disposal of landfill gas using modern methods of calculating, techniques, and materials was developed. The system is adapted to the conditions of landfill No. 5 (Kiev region) and includes utilization of 600-800 m3/h LFG to generate ∼1 MW of electricity. Original technical solutions allowed us to develop the system at operational landfill. Mathematical modeling of the system was carried out with the software system GasCondOil on the basis of thermodynamic modeling, using the massive of experimental data and the programming phase transitions, properties, and processes. The calculations obtain the basic characteristics of the system: the material balance of LFG in the system, the pressure diff erence (input-output) in all sections of pipelines, the gas flow rate, phase composition, and flow. The system was analyzed for the absence of out-of-range of parameters. Technological developments have been successfully implemented at the landfill by LNK Company, one of the leading ones in the field of LFG utilization in Ukraine. A station was created for LFG processing into electricity by a block of five gas generators, TEDOM Cento 180 (Czech Republic). The system transmits electricity produced to the centralized network on an ongoing basis. The station is the first stage of the complex, designed to produce 4.5 MW of electricity. This first stage system allows reducing annual methane pollution by 30,000 MT CO2eqv. © 2013 by Begell House, Inc.

Title: The investigation of solar energy conversion and storage processes in biomass
Source title: 8th International Conference on Electrical and Control Technologies, ECT 2013

Authors with affiliations: Sirvydas, P.A., Aleksandras Stulginskis University, Lithuania; Kučinskas, V., UAB ARVI ir ko, Lithuania
Abstract: The transformation and accumulation of solar energy in a biological form has direct relationships with food, biomass energy and climate change problems, which can be addressed as the processes of the exchange of energies in the plant. The analysis of these processes helps understand the factors affecting the process of the plant's energy exchange. Biomass can only release the amount of energy equal to the radiant energy assimilated by it from the Sun in the process of biomass production. Solar energy accumulation in biomass is highly inefficient as a mere 2 % of the provided energy is used. The remaining share of energy is emitted to the environment. The regulation system of plant leaf temperature may be one of theoretical presumptions for the efficient cooling of microchips. © Kaunas University of Technology, 2013.

Authors: Greenwood W., Cheng F., Lavrova O., Mammoli A., Willard S.
Title: Day-ahead cumulative solar irradiance prediction method using percent cloud cover forecasts
Source title: 42nd ASES National Solar Conference 2013, SOLAR 2013, Including 42nd ASES Annual Conference and 38th National Passive Solar Conference
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM  87131, United States; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM  87131, United States; Public Service Company of New Mexico (PNM), Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Greenwood, W., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM  87131, United States; Cheng, F., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM  87131, United States; Lavrova, O., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM  87131, United States; Mammoli, A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, NM  87131, United States; Willard, S., Public Service Company of New Mexico (PNM), Mexico
Abstract: A method for forecasting solar irradiance has been developed. The goal of this study was to explore the applicability of cloud cover forecasts, typically used to determine visibility for aviation, for solar PV irradiance prediction. Using known equations which define solar position, a theoretical clear-day irradiance profile was calculated specifically for a solar array located near Mesa del Sol in Albuquerque, New Mexico, USA. Percent cloud cover forecasts posted by the National Weather Service (NWS) were then combined with the theoretical data to predict actual irradiance experienced by the array. The cloud cover forecasts do not differentiate cloud types (for example, storm fronts or non-precipitating stratus clouds) which could affect irradiance differently. Nonetheless, a weighting constant was applied to percentages such that, at 100% cloud cover, a minimum irradiance exists. Predictions were calculated for dates with recorded irradiance data, allowing for comparison and optimization of weighting. This comparison was done both for raw data, which for cloudy days was highly variable, and a sliding average of the same data. Comparing predicted versus measured irradiance provided scatter-plots which could be influenced by modifying the weighting constant. Numeric optimization was then performed to minimize either the irradiance or daily energy prediction error. After developing this prediction method, it is apparent there are opportunities for improvement over using only percent cloud cover, such as incorporating precipitation forecasts to characterize the nature of the clouds. This method could be used to estimate energy production of a solar field, which is useful for storage optimization and energy resource scheduling. Copyright © (2013) by American Solar Energy Society.

Authors: Krause F., Bach W., Koomey J.
Title: Energy policy in the greenhouse: From warming fate to warming limit
Source title: Energy Policy in the Greenhouse: From Warming Fate to Warming Limit
Authors with affiliations: Krause, F.; Bach, W.; Koomey, J.
Abstract: The globe is warming and while no one knows what will happen as a result, it is clear that slowing the process is a necessary goal. Other studies have considered 'warming fates', this one brings sophisticated computer modeling to bear on ways of minimizing the risks.Fossil carbon emissions, other trace gases and releases from other sources are all taken into account, and the authors demonstrate the global need to produce a budget for cumulative releases between now and the year 2100. They also demonstrate the need to return to a rate of forest carbon storage equal to that of the mid-1980s. These budgets look at issues of international equity and the ways of moving to a binding agreement. The price of failure to control GHG emissions may be uncertain, but it will be more than anyone can afford. Political will lies at the root of successful climate stabilization and major capital and technology transfers to Third World countries will be needed if there is to be any chance of success. This book provides an agenda for advance. ?A book [which] throws into stark relief the mountain still to be climbed before the world community can agree on a credible programme to tackle global warming.? David Thomas, Financial Times Originally published in 1991 © 1989, 1990 International Project for Sustainable Energy Paths.

Authors: Allaoua B., Laoufi A., Mebarki B.
Title: Bat optimization for a dual-source energy management in an electric vehicle energy storage strategy
Source title: ECTI Transactions on Electrical Engineering, Electronics, and Communications
Affiliations: Department of Technology, BECHAR University, Algeria
Authors with affiliations: Allaoua, B., Department of Technology, BECHAR University, Algeria; Laoufi, A., Department of Technology, BECHAR University, Algeria; Mebarki, B., Department of Technology, BECHAR University, Algeria
Abstract: This paper presents a new strategy of dual source management using Bat-optimization for an electric vehicle energy storage strategy. The power distribution between fuel cell and super-capacitor modules for obtain a good performance is an essential problem in dual-source electric vehicles. Traditional numerical optimization for energy management relies too much on the expert experience, and it's easy to get the sub-optimal performance. In order to overcome this drawback, a new intelligent method metaheuristic of Bat optimization is introduced for energy management in dual-source propelled electric vehicle. This work, based on the systemic power analysis in the energy storage strategy, the vehicle power propulsion system encounters and the constraints the energy storage strategy should obey. Then, difierent operation modes of dual-source systemic power analysis in energy storage strategy are presented. Finally, the results show the validity of the proposed technique.
Author Keywords: Bat Algorithm; Dual-Source; Electric Vehicle; Energy Management; Energy Storage Strategy; Optimization Method

Authors: Pajusalu M., Lillmaa H., Ilbis E., Raabe R., Polevskis J., Lätt S., Noorma M.
Title: Comparison of simple-to-produce custom solar panel simulator approaches for developing nanosatellite power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the International Astronautical Congress, IAC
Affiliations: University of Tartu, Estonia; Ventspils University College, Latvia; University of Tartu, Estonia and Tartu Observatory, Estonia
Authors with affiliations: Pajusalu, M., University of Tartu, Estonia; Lillmaa, H., University of Tartu, Estonia; Ilbis, E., University of Tartu, Estonia; Raabe, R., University of Tartu, Estonia; Polevskis, J., Ventspils University College, Latvia; Lätt, S., University of Tartu, Estonia and Tartu Observatory, Estonia; Noorma, M., University of Tartu, Estonia and Tartu Observatory, Estonia
Abstract: To confirm that power harvesting, distribution, and storage systems of a satellite are working in an expected manner, and to determine their characteristics, a solar panel simulator has to be used to replicate the electrical properties of the satellite's solar arrays. Although these systems can be bought commercially, the commercial systems are generally intended for larger solar panels than those of nanosatellites and therefore are not very cost-efficient to use, especially in more complex power harvesting architectures that require the simulation of many independent solar panels at once. In this work we describe how we developed and used solar panel simulators in the ESTCube-1 nanosatellite project, mostly concentrating on a simple diode based solution. Index Keywords: Electric properties; Energy harvesting; Nanosatellites; Simulators; Commercial systems; Cost-efficient; Nanosatellite; Power harvesting; Solar arrays; Solar panel simulators; Solar panels; Storage systems; Solar concentrators

Authors: Cherki A., Khabbazi A., Idchabani R., Garoum M.
Title: Experimental study of thermal insulation, energy storage capacity and lightness of cork-gypsum composite
Affiliations: Université Med V-Agdal, Laboratoire Énergétique, Matériaux et Environnement, 227 Avenue Prince héritier EST, Salé, Morocco
Authors with affiliations: Cherki, A., Université Med V-Agdal, Laboratoire Énergétique, Matériaux et Environnement, 227 Avenue Prince héritier EST, Salé, Morocco; Khabbazi, A., Université Med V-Agdal, Laboratoire Énergétique, Matériaux et Environnement, 227 Avenue Prince héritier EST, Salé, Morocco; Idchabani, R., Université Med V-Agdal, Laboratoire Énergétique, Matériaux et Environnement, 227 Avenue Prince héritier EST, Salé, Morocco; Garoum, M., Université Med V-Agdal, Laboratoire Énergétique, Matériaux et Environnement, 227 Avenue Prince héritier EST, Salé, Morocco
Abstract: This work describes a composite material based on granular cork bound with gypsum. It is a complex medium with a double porosity: the first is that of granular cork having an irregular forms and the other relative to gypsum. An experimental study was conducted on this material in order to characterize its thermal properties. Its thermal properties were compared with those of gypsum for motivate the proposal that cork-gypsum material will be used as false ceiling. Finally, the energy performances of this material were compared with those of gypsum without cork. The findings of experiments indicate that corkgypsum materiel is better than gypsum without cork in term of thermal insulation, energy storage capacity and slowness of heat transmission; the material is also significantly lighter than gypsum without cork. Its utilization as false ceiling will allow deducing a very interesting energy gain and will be then a contribution to improve energy efficiency in buildings.
Author Keywords: Cork-gypsum composite; Energy efficiency; False ceiling; Granular cork; Gypsum; Sustainable building material

Title: The effect of production and storage on the content of vitamin C in NFC orange juice
Affiliations: Latvia University of Agriculture, Latvia
Authors with affiliations: Zvaigzne, G., Latvia University of Agriculture, Latvia; Karklina, D., Latvia University of Agriculture, Latvia
Abstract: The traditional consumption of citrus juices as a breakfast beverage has historical ties to obtaining one's daily requirement of vitamin C. Vitamin C is one of the most important vitamins found in citrus juices, including orange juice. The aim of the study was to determine the effect of processing and storage on the content of vitamin C in orange juice varieties of 'Valencia' and 'Navel' of orange juice. The content of vitamin C (mg 100 g-1) was determined with the iodine method in freshly squeezed orange juices and in pasteurized and packaged in aseptic bags orange juices of 'Valencia 'and 'Navel' variety, after processing and during 24 weeks of storage at 20 ± 1 °C and 5 ± 1 °C. The study results showed that the average content of vitamin C in freshly squeezed orange juice 'Valencia' was found at 33.56 mg 100g-1 but in freshly squeezed orange juice 'Navel' the content of vitamin C was higher than in 'Valencia' variety orange juice average at 46.18 mg 100g-1. The loss of vitamin C for both orange juices on average about 7% during processing The storage study showed that after 24 weeks of storage at 5 ± 1 °C and at 20 ± 1 °C, in pasteurized orange juice 'Valencia' the content of vitamin C decreased by 9.83% and 19.73 respectively. In the pasteurized orange juice 'Navel' the content of vitamin C decreased by 8.53% and 15.24% respectively.
Author Keywords: 'Navel' NFC orange juice; 'Valencia'; Storage; Vitamin C
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Pasteurization; Energy storage; Fruit juices; Pasteurization; Citrus juices; Orange juice; Storage studies; Valencia; Vitamin C; Fruit juices; Citrus fruits

Title: High energy density physics at AWE
Source title: 2013 Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics, CLEO 2013
Abstract: AWE is tasked with supporting Continuous At Sea Deterrence (CASD) by certifying the performance and safety of the deterrent in the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) era. Certification must be achieved by supplementing historical nuclear test data with use of computer calculations. AWE therefore regularly procures, installs and operates large supercomputers, and complements this with high end storage, network, visualisation and desktop systems that enable the supercomputers to be exploited effectively. This High Performance Computing (HPC) environment is useless without computer programmes or 'codes' to run on it. Multi-physics algorithms are developed to solve the equations of compressible fluid flow coupled to transport algorithms and other required physics such as fusion burn. These state-of-the-art algorithms are in turn worthless without material property data. It is particularly challenging to obtain required material properties such as opacity and equation of state in the extreme conditions of interest. The requirements span timescales of many orders of magnitude and pressures up to Gigabars with temperatures ranging up to tens of millions of degrees. The regimes of hot dense matter (HDM) and warm dense matter (WDM) are pertinent, representing material that is heated while remaining at a density close to solid; similar conditions exist in the cores of large planets and in the sun. In some cases it is possible to harness the power of HPC to calculate the material properties but even if this is the case, it is always important to underpin calculated properties with measurements in appropriate conditions. Once the material property data have been incorporated into the multi-physics codes, meaningful calculations become possible. It is then necessary to carry out further experiments to validate the codes and indeed the designers who are using them. It turns out that an excellent way to meet many of the requirements for material property data and to provide confidence in the validity of the algorithms is through experiments carried out on high power laser systems. © 2013 The Optical Society.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Codes (symbols); Equations of state; Experiments; High power lasers; Supercomputers; Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty; Compressible fluid flow; Computer calculation; High energy density physics; High performance computing (HPC); High-power laser systems; Material property datum; State-of-the-art algorithms; Digital storage
